We dateren de brief daarom tussen 18 en 31 oktober 1909.
Zie voor de verhuizing van De Iongh naar Den Haag MEP_1295.In oktober 1909 begonnen Aletta (viool) en Anna (cello) de Iongh aan hun studie aan het Koninklijk Conservatorium te Den Haag (Van Heteren 2018, p. 42).Het jaarlijkse gecostumeerde bal van kunstenaarsvereniging Sint Lucas had dat jaar als thema Spanje en vond plaats op zaterdag 13 november 1909 in het Hotel Americain te Amsterdam. In september 1903 had Mondriaan tijdens een reis naar Frankrijk en Spanje een stierengevecht bijgewoond in de arena van Bilbao (Gorter 1998, p. 27-32 and Coppes 2018, p. 124); [ill.].Met de 'dingen uit Zeeland' bedoelt Mondriaan de schetsen die hij in de zomer van 1909 had gemaakt tijdens zijn verblijf in de kunstprovincie. In Amsterdam zou hij de schetsen uitwerken tot volwaardige schilderijen, waarvan hij de volgende werken in het voorjaar van 1910 presenteerde op de Voorjaarstentoonstelling van Sint Lucas: [**Zeeland farmer**] (A675), [**Zeeland girl**] (A676), [**Little house in sunlight**] (A679), [**Sun, church in Zeeland**] (A689) en [**Summer, dune in Zeeland**] (A708).Op de tentoonstelling Teekeningen en Beeldhouwwerken van leden van Arti et Amicitiae (17 oktober - 21 november) stelde Mondriaan de tekening [**Lily**] (A619) tentoon. 'Pecuniae causa' is Latijn voor 'ter wille van het geld'.
Sarphatip. 42.
Dear Zus,
I was very pleased to hear from you again. It’s good that you can adjust so well and that it’s not too disappointing, the new surroundings etc.It will be very nice for your Ma to have you both with her. And, as you write, your work is the main thing, after all, and when you’re busy you don’t miss a lot of things that may be lacking or desirable!I’ve already been to the Philipponas’ a few times; they also think it’s a great pity that you have both gone and they’re still doing all right. It would be nice if you both came here on 13 November; I think you’ll enjoy it. There will be a performance and I shall put together a bullfight because I’ve seen that.I’m thinking of going in black velvet, if it doesn’t work out too dear. I’ll find out for you what a lady’s costume costs, because I’ve heard we can get it much cheaper as a combination. So I’ll write to you about it; it would be much nicer if you went in costume. I shall try to get Reinier as a matador too.
I haven’t started on the things from Zeeland yet.I have made a few flowers (one of them is at Arti now), and now I’m working on some small paintings I can sell; tiresome to have to do this because it has to be the way people want, but it’s pecuniae causa.I shall be very pleased with that velvet tie! Don’t make it as a ribbon, but with a loop around the stud? From the back these ties (for double collars) look something like this: [drawing of tie with note:] That goes behind the collar. loop [end of note]
Now, my dear child, I hope you won’t have to spend too much time on it, and end now with many warm wishes, to Annie, too, your friend
 Piet.

Zie voor de verhuizing van De Iongh naar Den Haag MEP_1295.
In oktober 1909 begonnen Aletta (viool) en Anna (cello) de Iongh aan hun studie aan het Koninklijk Conservatorium te Den Haag (Van Heteren 2018, p. 42).

Het jaarlijkse gecostumeerde bal van kunstenaarsvereniging Sint Lucas had dat jaar als thema Spanje en vond plaats op zaterdag 13 november 1909 in het Hotel Americain te Amsterdam. In september 1903 had Mondriaan tijdens een reis naar Frankrijk en Spanje een stierengevecht bijgewoond in de arena van Bilbao (Gorter 1998, p. 27-32 and Coppes 2018, p. 124); [ill.].

Met de 'dingen uit Zeeland' bedoelt Mondriaan de schetsen die hij in de zomer van 1909 had gemaakt tijdens zijn verblijf in de kunstprovincie. In Amsterdam zou hij de schetsen uitwerken tot volwaardige schilderijen, waarvan hij de volgende werken in het voorjaar van 1910 presenteerde op de Voorjaarstentoonstelling van Sint Lucas: [**Zeeland farmer**] (A675), [**Zeeland girl**] (A676), [**Little house in sunlight**] (A679), [**Sun, church in Zeeland**] (A689) en [**Summer, dune in Zeeland**] (A708).

Op de tentoonstelling Teekeningen en Beeldhouwwerken van leden van Arti et Amicitiae (17 oktober - 21 november) stelde Mondriaan de tekening [**Lily**] (A619) tentoon. 'Pecuniae causa' is Latijn voor 'ter wille van het geld'.

Beste Zus,
ik zou je nog schrijven betreffende den prijs van kostuums voor 't feest. Nu, 't is alles even duur. Helmhout gaf op ff. 5 voor gewone en ff. 7.50 voor kostbare pakken, nu zullen ze van Lucas er wat af zien te krijgen.Ik schrijf 't je maar, misschien weet je zelf goedkooper adres, of kom je ongekostumeerd.
Mijn vorige brief heb je zeker ontvangen.
Met vele beste groeten
 in haast, je toegen. Piet.
Manuscript.Mondriaan komt in deze brief terug op de belofte die hij deed in brief MEP_1297 betreffende navraag naar kostuums voor het Spaanse Feest bij Sint Lucas. Die brief dateert op zijn vroegst van 18 oktober 1909; daarmee zal de onderhavige op zijn vroegst op 19 oktober geschreven zijn (al kunnen uiteraard meer dan een dag tussen beide brieven verlopen zijn). De brief moet zijn verstuurd voor brief MEP_1299, aangezien Mondriaan daarin na nog verder geïnformeerd te hebben de conclusie trekt dat de huurprijzen voor feestkleding te hoog zijn en De Iongh aanraadt zelf voor kleding te zorgen. Omdat die brief op zijn vroegst op zondag 7 november is geschreven en Mondriaans verder informeren waarschijnlijk (minimaal) enkele dagen in beslag genomen zal hebben, stellen we de terminus ante quem op c. woensdag 3 november. Daarom dateren we de onderhavige brief tussen dinsdag 19 oktober en c. woensdag 3 november.Het themafeest van Sint Lucas (MEP_1297).
Verschillende leden van Sint Lucas huurden hun kostuum bij het Nederlands Costuum-Magazijn Helmhout & Co, gevestigd op Singel 153 (AAA 1909-1910).
Dear Zus,
I was supposed to write to you about the price of costumes for the party. Well, they’re all just as dear. Helmhout charges f 5 for ordinary and f 7.50 for expensive outfits, the Lucas people will see if they can get something off.I just thought I’d let you know, you may know a cheaper place, or come without a costume. You must have received my last letter.
With very best wishes,
 in haste, from your affectionate Piet.

Waarde Arnold Saalborn,
ik zal maar niet "mijnheer" schrijven, ik hoop U mij ook Mondriaan zonder mijnheer voortaan zult noemen.
Hartelijk dank voor Uw schrijven. Als ik weêr eens wat meer tijd heb zal ik U graag wat meer van mijn werk laten zien.Maar daar ik met mijn schilderwerk niet veel verdien, moet ik ook veel tijd besteden aan werk voor de massa, dus schilderwerk op een meer conventioneele manier en dus moet ik dubbel werken. Van daar dat ik me wel heel concentreeren moet, wil ik nog iets bereiken.
Ik woû U nog een paar dingen schrijven, maar veel schrijven naar aanleiding van wat U schreef, lijkt me niet goed omdat 't altoos te onvolledig zal zijn en U dus toch niet den een onjuisten beeld van mijn denken zou krijgen. Er zijn zoovele factoren die menschen van overigens dezelfde gevoelens en aanleg, toch tijdelijk doen verschillen; zoo onder andere levenservaringen of levensomstandigheden etc. etc. — dan 't soort werk dat men doet, etc. etc- .etc.— Dat zijn schijnbaar alle kleine dingen maar die van invloed zijn op de openbaring van 't uiterlijke leven v.d. menschen en artisten, vindt U ook niet?
Zoo b.v. zal er verschil zijn (niet in wezen, maar in leefwijze) tusschen ieen artist die van zijn produkt moet leven, en een, die toch kan leven: ik noem maar eens wat, om aan te toonen dat dergelijke dingen toch alle regels en wetten (zooals U er eene opnoemt, n.l. dat alleen blijven niet goed is, als ik U wel begrijp) — omver stooten.
Over dat zelfde alleen zijn wilde ik U nog deze gedachte zeggen: ik vind dat de gewone mensch de mooiheden zoekt in 't reëele leven, maar de artist moet dit naar mijn idée niet. Hij moet niets reëels willen: hij moet alleen en heel alleen staan. Hij moet scheppen uit enkel scheppingsdrang: net als de heele natuur, maar scheppen op een voor ons onreëel gebied, dat der gedachte. En als hij enkel gehoorzaam aan dien scheppingsdrang is, en zich vrij houdt zooveel mogelijk opdat hij dat zal kunnen, dan doet hij genoeg. En dan volgt daaruit dat hij heel veel voor de menschheid zal zijn. Ik lees daar nog eens over dat U schrijft: alleen zijn is zeer verderfelijk, vooral voor de grooten en edelen onder de menschen. Ik moet U ronduit zeggen dat ik juist 't tegendeel zou beweren. Alleen zijn is (voor de grooten) 't indringen en kennen van 't Zelf, van den eigelijken mensch, van den godmensch en god, in hoogste instantie. Dus volgt hieruit grooter worden, bewust worden — eindelijk God worden.Hoe zou dit verderfelijk kunnen zijn? Maar wellicht bedoelt U 't ook anders, dan en daarom lijkt mij ´t beste dat we later nog eens praten over 't een en ander.
Dus veel beste groeten van
 Piet Mondriaan.
Fotokopie van manuscript.Op de fotokopie van de brief is te zien dat een andere hand een opschrift in de rechterbovenhoek van p. 1r:1 'overtrok'. Er staat nu '31 Jan. 1916. Sarfatipark 42.' Afgezien van de onjuiste spelling van het adres (juist is 'Sarphatipark') woonde Mondriaan in 1916 te Laren. Uit de brief is bovendien merkbaar dat Saalborn en Mondriaan elkaar nog niet lang kennen. Aangezien Mondriaan achterop de olieverfstudie Dying sunflower II een opdracht aan Saalborn schreef met de datering 'Januari 1910', ligt voor de hand dat de aangevulde datering op de kopie 1910 had moeten zijn. We dateren daarom de brief op maandag 31 januari 1910.Engelse vertaling in Holtzman/James 1986, p. 19 en 394, n. 29. Behalve de aanhef en de slotfrasen ontbreken in de vertaling (met weglatingsteken) de regels 101-109 ('Ik woû u nog ... denken zou krijgen.').
Kennelijk was Saalborn eerder kort bij Mondriaan in het atelier op Sarphatipark 42 geweest. Bij die gelegenheid kan Mondriaan Saalborn zijn Dying sunflower II gegeven hebben; op de achterzijde van het schilderij schreef Mondriaan: 'Van Piet Mondriaan aan Arnold Saalborn, met sympathie voor den schrijver van Zonnesproke en De Schooier. Januari 1910'. 'Zonnesproke' en 'De schooier' waren symbolistische verhalen die Saalborn gepubliceerd had in respectievelijk De Kunst (28 augustus 1909) en Amsterdamsche studenten-almanak voor het jaar 1910, jg. 80, p. 346-355 (uitgegeven in 1909).Het streven naar een steeds hogere staat van geestelijk bewustzijn is geënt op de theosofische leer, waarvan Mondriaan een aanhanger was. (Op 25 mei 1909 was Mondriaan toegetreden tot de Theosofische Vereniging). Vergelijk ook brief MEP_1309 aan Aletta de Iongh van oktober 1910, waarin hij schrijft dat Theosofie 'werkelijk een leiddraad tot ontwikkeling van je bewustzijn' is.
Dear Arnold Saalborn,
I shall not write “Mr”, in the hope that you will also call me Mondriaan without the “Mr” from now on.
Thank you very much for your letter. Once I have rather more time, I will be happy to show you more of my work.But since I do not earn much with my painting, I also have to spend a lot of time on work for the masses, painting in a more conventional way, and so I have double the work to do. That’s why I must concentrate very hard if I still wish to achieve anything.
I wanted to tell you a few more things, but I don’t think that writing a lot in response to what you wrote is a good idea because it will always be too incomplete and so you would gain an incorrect impression of my thinking. There are so many factors that make people with the same feelings and disposition nonetheless differ temporarily; amongst other things, life experiences or living conditions, etc., etc. – And then the kind of work one does, etc., etc. – These all seem like small things, but they influence the manifestation of the outward life of people and artists, don’t you agree?
So, e.g., there will be a difference (not in essence, but in way of living) between an artist who has to live from his product and one who can live anyway; that’s just one example, to show that such things overturn all rules and laws (like one you mention, namely that remaining alone is not good, if I understand you correctly).
On that same topic, being alone, I also wanted to share this thought with you: I believe that the ordinary person looks to real life for beauty, but in my opinion the artist should not do that. He should not want anything real: he should stand alone, entirely alone. He should create purely out of the urge to create, just like all of nature does, but creating in an area that is unreal to us, that of thought. And if he is obedient only to that creative urge, keeping himself as free as possible so that he is able to, then he is doing enough. And from that it follows that he will mean a great deal for mankind. I read again that you write: being alone is most pernicious, especially for great and noble people. I must tell you frankly that I would argue the exact opposite. Being alone is (for the great) infiltrating and knowing the Self, the true person, the god-man and god, on the highest plane. And from that becoming greater, becoming aware – and in the end becoming God.How can this be pernicious? But perhaps you mean it differently, and so that’s why I think it would be best if we talk more about these things later.
Many best regards
, then, from Piet Mondriaan.
Photocopy of manuscript.On the photocopy of this letter, it can be seen that an inscription in the top right-hand corner of p. 1r:1 has been overwritten in another hand. It now reads: “31 Jan. 1916. Sarfatipark 42.” Quite apart from the incorrect spelling of the Amsterdam address (it should be “Sarphatipark”), Mondrian was living in Laren in 1916. It is also clear from this letter that Saalborn and Mondrian have not known each other for long. Since Mondrian wrote a dedication to Saalborn on the back of the study in oils Dying Sunflower II with the date January 1910, it seems most likely that the dating added to the copy should also have been 1910. We therefore date this letter to 31 January 1910.English translation in Holtzman/James 1986, pp. 19 and 394, n. 29. As well as the salutation and the final greeting, that version also omits (with ellipsis) the sentence “I wanted to tell you… impression of my thinking”.
Saalborn had apparently already paid a brief visit to Mondrian’s studio at Sarphatipark 42. On that occasion the artist may have given him the painting Dying sunflower II; on the back of that work, he wrote: “From Piet Mondriaan to Arnold Saalborn, with sympathy for the writer of Zonnesproke and De Schooier. January 1910.” Zonnesproke (Tale of the Sun) and De Schooier (The Vagabond) were symbolist short stories Saalborn had published in, respectively, De Kunst (28 August 1909) and Amsterdamsche studenten-almanak voor het jaar 1910 (the Amsterdam student almanac for 1910, actually published in 1909; vol. 80, pp. 346-355).The pursuit of an ever higher state of spiritual consciousness is based upon the theosophical doctrine, to which Mondrian adhered. He had joined the Dutch Theosophical Society on 25 May 1909. Cf. also letter MEP_1309 of October 1910 to Aletta de Iongh, in which he writes that Theosophy “truly [is] a guide to the development of your consciousness”.

I shall not write “Mr”, in the hope that you will also call me Mondriaan without the “Mr” from now on.
Thank you very much for your letter. Once I have rather more time, I will be happy to show you more of my work.[1] But since I do not earn much with my painting, I also have to spend a lot of time on work for the masses, painting in a more conventional way, and so I have double the work to do. That’s why I must concentrate very hard if I still wish to achieve anything.
I wanted to tell you a few more things, but I don’t think that writing a lot in response to what you wrote is a good idea because it will always be too incomplete and so you would gain an incorrect impression of my thinking. There are so many factors that make people with the same feelings and disposition nonetheless differ temporarily; amongst other things, life experiences or living conditions, etc., etc. – And then the kind of work one does, etc., etc. – These all seem like small things, but they influence the manifestation of the outward life of people and artists, don’t you agree?
So, e.g., there will be a difference (not in essence, but in way of living) between an artist who has to live from his product and one who can live anyway; that’s just one example, to show that such things overturn all rules and laws (like one you mention, namely that remaining alone is not good, if I understand you correctly).
On that same topic, being alone, I also wanted to share this thought with you: I believe that the ordinary person looks to real life for beauty, but in my opinion the artist should not do that. He should not want anything real: he should stand alone, entirely alone. He should create purely out of the urge to create, just like all of nature does, but creating in an area that is unreal to us, that of thought. And if he is obedient only to that creative urge, keeping himself as free as possible so that he is able to, then he is doing enough. I must tell you frankly that I would argue the exact opposite. Being alone is (for the great) infiltrating and knowing the Self, the true person, the god-man and god, on the highest plane. And from that becoming greater, becoming aware – and in the end becoming God.[2] How can this be pernicious? But perhaps you mean it differently, and so that’s why I think it would be best if we talk more about these things later.
Many kind regards, then, from

En dan volgt daaruit dat hij heel veel voor de menschheid zal zijn. Ik lees daar nog eens over dat U schrijft: alleen zijn is zeer verderfelijk, vooral voor de grooten en edelen onder de menschen. Ik moet U ronduit zeggen dat ik juist 't tegendeel zou beweren. Alleen zijn is (voor de grooten) 't indringen en kennen van 't Zelf, van den eigelijken mensch, van den godmensch en god, in hoogste instantie. Dus volgt hieruit grooter worden, bewust worden — eindelijk God worden.Hoe zou dit verderfelijk kunnen zijn? Maar wellicht bedoelt U 't ook anders, dan en daarom lijkt mij ´t beste dat we later nog eens praten over 't een en ander.
Dus veel beste groeten van
 Piet Mondriaan.
ik zal maar niet "mijnheer" schrijven, ik hoop U mij ook Mondriaan zonder mijnheer voortaan zult noemen.

Hartelijk dank voor Uw schrijven. Als ik weêr eens wat meer tijd heb zal ik U graag wat meer van mijn werk laten zien.Maar daar ik met mijn schilderwerk niet veel verdien, moet ik ook veel tijd besteden aan werk voor de massa, dus schilderwerk op een meer conventioneele manier en dus moet ik dubbel werken. Van daar dat ik me wel heel concentreeren moet, wil ik nog iets bereiken.

Ik woû U nog een paar dingen schrijven, maar veel schrijven naar aanleiding van wat U schreef, lijkt me niet goed omdat 't altoos te onvolledig zal zijn en U dus toch niet den een onjuisten beeld van mijn denken zou krijgen. Er zijn zoovele factoren die menschen van overigens dezelfde gevoelens en aanleg, toch tijdelijk doen verschillen; zoo onder andere levenservaringen of levensomstandigheden etc. etc. — dan 't soort werk dat men doet, etc. etc- .etc.— Dat zijn schijnbaar alle kleine dingen maar die van invloed zijn op de openbaring van 't uiterlijke leven v.d. menschen en artisten, vindt U ook niet?

Zoo b.v. zal er verschil zijn (niet in wezen, maar in leefwijze) tusschen ieen artist die van zijn produkt moet leven, en een, die toch kan leven: ik noem maar eens wat, om aan te toonen dat dergelijke dingen toch alle regels en wetten (zooals U er eene opnoemt, n.l. dat alleen blijven niet goed is, als ik U wel begrijp) — omver stooten.
Over dat zelfde alleen zijn wilde ik U nog deze gedachte zeggen: ik vind dat de gewone mensch de mooiheden zoekt in 't reëele leven, maar de artist moet dit naar mijn idée niet. Hij moet niets reëels willen: hij moet alleen en heel alleen staan. Fotokopie van manuscript.Op de fotokopie van de brief is te zien dat een andere hand een opschrift in de rechterbovenhoek van p. 1r:1 'overtrok'. Er staat nu '31 Jan. 1916. Sarfatipark 42.' Afgezien van de onjuiste spelling van het adres (juist is 'Sarphatipark') woonde Mondriaan in 1916 te Laren. Uit de brief is bovendien merkbaar dat Saalborn en Mondriaan elkaar nog niet lang kennen. Aangezien Mondriaan achterop de olieverfstudie Dying sunflower II een opdracht aan Saalborn schreef met de datering 'Januari 1910', ligt voor de hand dat de aangevulde datering op de kopie 1910 had moeten zijn. We dateren daarom de brief op maandag 31 januari 1910.Engelse vertaling in Holtzman/James 1986, p. 19 en 394, n. 29. Behalve de aanhef en de slotfrasen ontbreken in de vertaling (met weglatingsteken) de regels 101-109 ('Ik woû u nog ... denken zou krijgen.').
Kennelijk was Saalborn eerder kort bij Mondriaan in het atelier op Sarphatipark 42 geweest. Bij die gelegenheid kan Mondriaan Saalborn zijn Dying sunflower II gegeven hebben; op de achterzijde van het schilderij schreef Mondriaan: 'Van Piet Mondriaan aan Arnold Saalborn, met sympathie voor den schrijver van Zonnesproke en De Schooier. Januari 1910'. 'Zonnesproke' en 'De schooier' waren symbolistische verhalen die Saalborn gepubliceerd had in respectievelijk De Kunst (28 augustus 1909) en Amsterdamsche studenten-almanak voor het jaar 1910, jg. 80, p. 346-355 (uitgegeven in 1909).Het streven naar een steeds hogere staat van geestelijk bewustzijn is geënt op de theosofische leer, waarvan Mondriaan een aanhanger was. (Op 25 mei 1909 was Mondriaan toegetreden tot de Theosofische Vereniging). Vergelijk ook brief MEP_1309 aan Aletta de Iongh van oktober 1910, waarin hij schrijft dat Theosofie 'werkelijk een leiddraad tot ontwikkeling van je bewustzijn' is.
Dear Arnold Saalborn,
I shall not write “Mr”, in the hope that you will also call me Mondriaan without the “Mr” from now on.
Thank you very much for your letter. Once I have rather more time, I will be happy to show you more of my work.But since I do not earn much with my painting, I also have to spend a lot of time on work for the masses, painting in a more conventional way, and so I have double the work to do. That’s why I must concentrate very hard if I still wish to achieve anything.
I wanted to tell you a few more things, but I don’t think that writing a lot in response to what you wrote is a good idea because it will always be too incomplete and so you would gain an incorrect impression of my thinking. There are so many factors that make people with the same feelings and disposition nonetheless differ temporarily; amongst other things, life experiences or living conditions, etc., etc. – And then the kind of work one does, etc., etc. – These all seem like small things, but they influence the manifestation of the outward life of people and artists, don’t you agree?
So, e.g., there will be a difference (not in essence, but in way of living) between an artist who has to live from his product and one who can live anyway; that’s just one example, to show that such things overturn all rules and laws (like one you mention, namely that remaining alone is not good, if I understand you correctly).
On that same topic, being alone, I also wanted to share this thought with you: I believe that the ordinary person looks to real life for beauty, but in my opinion the artist should not do that. He should not want anything real: he should stand alone, entirely alone. He should create purely out of the urge to create, just like all of nature does, but creating in an area that is unreal to us, that of thought. And if he is obedient only to that creative urge, keeping himself as free as possible so that he is able to, then he is doing enough. And from that it follows that he will mean a great deal for mankind. I read again that you write: being alone is most pernicious, especially for great and noble people. I must tell you frankly that I would argue the exact opposite. Being alone is (for the great) infiltrating and knowing the Self, the true person, the god-man and god, on the highest plane. And from that becoming greater, becoming aware – and in the end becoming God.How can this be pernicious? But perhaps you mean it differently, and so that’s why I think it would be best if we talk more about these things later.
Many best regards
, then, from Piet Mondriaan.
Photocopy of manuscript.On the photocopy of this letter, it can be seen that an inscription in the top right-hand corner of p. 1r:1 has been overwritten in another hand. It now reads: “31 Jan. 1916. Sarfatipark 42.” Quite apart from the incorrect spelling of the Amsterdam address (it should be “Sarphatipark”), Mondrian was living in Laren in 1916. It is also clear from this letter that Saalborn and Mondrian have not known each other for long. Since Mondrian wrote a dedication to Saalborn on the back of the study in oils Dying Sunflower II with the date January 1910, it seems most likely that the dating added to the copy should also have been 1910. We therefore date this letter to 31 January 1910.English translation in Holtzman/James 1986, pp. 19 and 394, n. 29. As well as the salutation and the final greeting, that version also omits (with ellipsis) the sentence “I wanted to tell you… impression of my thinking”.
Saalborn had apparently already paid a brief visit to Mondrian’s studio at Sarphatipark 42. On that occasion the artist may have given him the painting Dying sunflower II; on the back of that work, he wrote: “From Piet Mondriaan to Arnold Saalborn, with sympathy for the writer of Zonnesproke and De Schooier. January 1910.” Zonnesproke (Tale of the Sun) and De Schooier (The Vagabond) were symbolist short stories Saalborn had published in, respectively, De Kunst (28 August 1909) and Amsterdamsche studenten-almanak voor het jaar 1910 (the Amsterdam student almanac for 1910, actually published in 1909; vol. 80, pp. 346-355).The pursuit of an ever higher state of spiritual consciousness is based upon the theosophical doctrine, to which Mondrian adhered. He had joined the Dutch Theosophical Society on 25 May 1909. Cf. also letter MEP_1309 of October 1910 to Aletta de Iongh, in which he writes that Theosophy “truly [is] a guide to the development of your consciousness”.
Dear Arnold Saalborn,
I shall not write “Mr”, in the hope that you will also call me Mondriaan without the “Mr” from now on.
Thank you very much for your letter. Once I have rather more time, I will be happy to show you more of my work.[1] But since I do not earn much with my painting, I also have to spend a lot of time on work for the masses, painting in a more conventional way, and so I have double the work to do. That’s why I must concentrate very hard if I still wish to achieve anything.
I wanted to tell you a few more things, but I don’t think that writing a lot in response to what you wrote is a good idea because it will always be too incomplete and so you would gain an incorrect impression of my thinking. There are so many factors that make people with the same feelings and disposition nonetheless differ temporarily; amongst other things, life experiences or living conditions, etc., etc. – And then the kind of work one does, etc., etc. – These all seem like small things, but they influence the manifestation of the outward life of people and artists, don’t you agree?
So, e.g., there will be a difference (not in essence, but in way of living) between an artist who has to live from his product and one who can live anyway; that’s just one example, to show that such things overturn all rules and laws (like one you mention, namely that remaining alone is not good, if I understand you correctly).
On that same topic, being alone, I also wanted to share this thought with you: I believe that the ordinary person looks to real life for beauty, but in my opinion the artist should not do that. He should not want anything real: he should stand alone, entirely alone. He should create purely out of the urge to create, just like all of nature does, but creating in an area that is unreal to us, that of thought. And if he is obedient only to that creative urge, keeping himself as free as possible so that he is able to, then he is doing enough. And from that it follows that he will mean a great deal for mankind. I read again that you write: being alone is most pernicious, especially for great and noble people. I must tell you frankly that I would argue the exact opposite. Being alone is (for the great) infiltrating and knowing the Self, the true person, the god-man and god, on the highest plane. And from that becoming greater, becoming aware – and in the end becoming God.[2] How can this be pernicious? But perhaps you mean it differently, and so that’s why I think it would be best if we talk more about these things later.
Many kind regards, then, from
 Piet Mondriaan.

Kennelijk was Saalborn eerder kort bij Mondriaan in het atelier op Sarphatipark 42 geweest. Bij die gelegenheid kan Mondriaan Saalborn zijn Dying sunflower II gegeven hebben; op de achterzijde van het schilderij schreef Mondriaan: 'Van Piet Mondriaan aan Arnold Saalborn, met sympathie voor den schrijver van Zonnesproke en De Schooier. Januari 1910'. 'Zonnesproke' en 'De schooier' waren symbolistische verhalen die Saalborn gepubliceerd had in respectievelijk De Kunst (28 augustus 1909) en Amsterdamsche studenten-almanak voor het jaar 1910, jg. 80, p. 346-355 (uitgegeven in 1909).

Het streven naar een steeds hogere staat van geestelijk bewustzijn is geënt op de theosofische leer, waarvan Mondriaan een aanhanger was. (Op 25 mei 1909 was Mondriaan toegetreden tot de Theosofische Vereniging). Vergelijk ook brief MEP_1309 aan Aletta de Iongh van oktober 1910, waarin hij schrijft dat Theosofie 'werkelijk een leiddraad tot ontwikkeling van je bewustzijn' is.

Dear Arnold Saalborn,
I shall not write “Mr”, in the hope that you will also call me Mondriaan without the “Mr” from now on.
Thank you very much for your letter. Once I have rather more time, I will be happy to show you more of my work.But since I do not earn much with my painting, I also have to spend a lot of time on work for the masses, painting in a more conventional way, and so I have double the work to do. That’s why I must concentrate very hard if I still wish to achieve anything.
I wanted to tell you a few more things, but I don’t think that writing a lot in response to what you wrote is a good idea because it will always be too incomplete and so you would gain an incorrect impression of my thinking. There are so many factors that make people with the same feelings and disposition nonetheless differ temporarily; amongst other things, life experiences or living conditions, etc., etc. – And then the kind of work one does, etc., etc. – These all seem like small things, but they influence the manifestation of the outward life of people and artists, don’t you agree?
So, e.g., there will be a difference (not in essence, but in way of living) between an artist who has to live from his product and one who can live anyway; that’s just one example, to show that such things overturn all rules and laws (like one you mention, namely that remaining alone is not good, if I understand you correctly).
On that same topic, being alone, I also wanted to share this thought with you: I believe that the ordinary person looks to real life for beauty, but in my opinion the artist should not do that. He should not want anything real: he should stand alone, entirely alone. He should create purely out of the urge to create, just like all of nature does, but creating in an area that is unreal to us, that of thought. And if he is obedient only to that creative urge, keeping himself as free as possible so that he is able to, then he is doing enough. And from that it follows that he will mean a great deal for mankind. I read again that you write: being alone is most pernicious, especially for great and noble people. I must tell you frankly that I would argue the exact opposite. Being alone is (for the great) infiltrating and knowing the Self, the true person, the god-man and god, on the highest plane. And from that becoming greater, becoming aware – and in the end becoming God.How can this be pernicious? But perhaps you mean it differently, and so that’s why I think it would be best if we talk more about these things later.
Many best regards
, then, from Piet Mondriaan.

Photocopy of manuscript.On the photocopy of this letter, it can be seen that an inscription in the top right-hand corner of p. 1r:1 has been overwritten in another hand. It now reads: “31 Jan. 1916. Sarfatipark 42.” Quite apart from the incorrect spelling of the Amsterdam address (it should be “Sarphatipark”), Mondrian was living in Laren in 1916. It is also clear from this letter that Saalborn and Mondrian have not known each other for long. Since Mondrian wrote a dedication to Saalborn on the back of the study in oils Dying Sunflower II with the date January 1910, it seems most likely that the dating added to the copy should also have been 1910. We therefore date this letter to 31 January 1910.English translation in Holtzman/James 1986, pp. 19 and 394, n. 29. As well as the salutation and the final greeting, that version also omits (with ellipsis) the sentence “I wanted to tell you… impression of my thinking”.
Saalborn had apparently already paid a brief visit to Mondrian’s studio at Sarphatipark 42. On that occasion the artist may have given him the painting Dying sunflower II; on the back of that work, he wrote: “From Piet Mondriaan to Arnold Saalborn, with sympathy for the writer of Zonnesproke and De Schooier. January 1910.” Zonnesproke (Tale of the Sun) and De Schooier (The Vagabond) were symbolist short stories Saalborn had published in, respectively, De Kunst (28 August 1909) and Amsterdamsche studenten-almanak voor het jaar 1910 (the Amsterdam student almanac for 1910, actually published in 1909; vol. 80, pp. 346-355).The pursuit of an ever higher state of spiritual consciousness is based upon the theosophical doctrine, to which Mondrian adhered. He had joined the Dutch Theosophical Society on 25 May 1909. Cf. also letter MEP_1309 of October 1910 to Aletta de Iongh, in which he writes that Theosophy “truly [is] a guide to the development of your consciousness”.

Dear Arnold Saalborn,
I shall not write “Mr”, in the hope that you will also call me Mondriaan without the “Mr” from now on.
Thank you very much for your letter. Once I have rather more time, I will be happy to show you more of my work.[1] But since I do not earn much with my painting, I also have to spend a lot of time on work for the masses, painting in a more conventional way, and so I have double the work to do. That’s why I must concentrate very hard if I still wish to achieve anything.
I wanted to tell you a few more things, but I don’t think that writing a lot in response to what you wrote is a good idea because it will always be too incomplete and so you would gain an incorrect impression of my thinking. There are so many factors that make people with the same feelings and disposition nonetheless differ temporarily; amongst other things, life experiences or living conditions, etc., etc. – And then the kind of work one does, etc., etc. – These all seem like small things, but they influence the manifestation of the outward life of people and artists, don’t you agree?
So, e.g., there will be a difference (not in essence, but in way of living) between an artist who has to live from his product and one who can live anyway; that’s just one example, to show that such things overturn all rules and laws (like one you mention, namely that remaining alone is not good, if I understand you correctly).
On that same topic, being alone, I also wanted to share this thought with you: I believe that the ordinary person looks to real life for beauty, but in my opinion the artist should not do that. He should not want anything real: he should stand alone, entirely alone. He should create purely out of the urge to create, just like all of nature does, but creating in an area that is unreal to us, that of thought. And if he is obedient only to that creative urge, keeping himself as free as possible so that he is able to, then he is doing enough. And from that it follows that he will mean a great deal for mankind. I read again that you write: being alone is most pernicious, especially for great and noble people. I must tell you frankly that I would argue the exact opposite. Being alone is (for the great) infiltrating and knowing the Self, the true person, the god-man and god, on the highest plane. And from that becoming greater, becoming aware – and in the end becoming God.[2] How can this be pernicious? But perhaps you mean it differently, and so that’s why I think it would be best if we talk more about these things later.
Many kind regards, then, from
 Piet Mondriaan.
